paragraphs.text:
%md
# Functional Programming - Function Composition and Chaining

more description [here][1]

Notes from [stackoverflow][2]

* Function has type, it defined by its arity and parameter type and return type; for example in Scala, 
```
val addOne: (Int) => Int = (x) => x + 1
```
We define a val (value), its name is `addOne`, which 
takes one parameter of type `Int` and return vaule of type `Int`, this is the type of this function. If we gives `Int` as parameter and returns a `Boolean`, it will be different type. This `value` is in the form of `function`.
the function is implemented as described after `=` sign.
In our example `x` is a parameter, can be any name,
return `x + 1`

* A function can be invoked with a list of arguments to produce a result. A function has a parameter list, a body, and a result type.
* Functions that are members of a class, trait, or singleton object are called methods. 
* Functions defined inside other functions are called local functions. 
* Functions with the result type of Unit are called procedures. 
* Anonymous functions in source code are called function literals. At run time, function literals are instantiated into objects called function values.
* Function can return a function; for [example][3]
```
def deferTaxCalculation(emp: Employee): () => Double = { 
    reallySlowTaxCalculator(emp)
}
```
deferTaxCalculator takes one `Employee` as parameter, then returns 
a function type `() = Double`, take no parameter and return a Double.



[1]:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Function_composition
[2]:http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2529184/difference-between-method-and-function-in-scala
[3]:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ugHsIj60VfQ

result.msg:
Functional Programming - Function Composition and Chaining

more description here

Notes from stackoverflow

  • Function has type, it defined by its arity and parameter type and return type; for example in Scala,

    val addOne: (Int) => Int = (x) => x + 1

    We define a val (value), its name is addOne, which
    takes one parameter of type Int and return vaule of type Int, this is the type of this function. If we gives Int as parameter and returns a Boolean, it will be different type. This value is in the form of function.
    the function is implemented as described after = sign.
    In our example x is a parameter, can be any name,
    return x + 1

  • A function can be invoked with a list of arguments to produce a result. A function has a parameter list, a body, and a result type.

  • Functions that are members of a class, trait, or singleton object are called methods.

  • Functions defined inside other functions are called local functions.

  • Functions with the result type of Unit are called procedures.

  • Anonymous functions in source code are called function literals. At run time, function literals are instantiated into objects called function values.

  • Function can return a function; for example

    def deferTaxCalculation(emp: Employee): () => Double = { 
reallySlowTaxCalculator(emp)
}

    deferTaxCalculator takes one Employee as parameter, then returns
    a function type () = Double, take no parameter and return a Double.

paragraphs.title: Input Data
paragraphs.text:
%spark
val ls = List(1,2,3,4)      //this is good for numbers are not in sequence
val ls0 = (1 to 4).toList   //this is good for numbers are in sequence, and long list

result.msg:
ls: List[Int] = List(1, 2, 3, 4)
ls0: List[Int] = List(1, 2, 3, 4)

paragraphs.title: Function - example

result.msg:
f: (x: Int)Int
res20: Int = 3
fs: (x: String)String
res21: String = 21

paragraphs.title: Function - example

result.msg:
g: (x: Int)Int
res33: Int = 4

paragraphs.text: %spark

%md
![function f][1]
[1]:https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rkuo/Zeppelin-Notebooks/master/2BNUH921M/images/f.png

%md
![function g][1]

[1]:https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rkuo/Zeppelin-Notebooks/master/2BNUH921M/images/g.png

paragraphs.title: Method vs Function
paragraphs.text:
%spark
// method vs function
// http://jim-mcbeath.blogspot.com/2009/05/scala-functions-vs-methods.html

def m1(x:Int) = x+3       //method
m1(2)
val f1 = (x:Int) => x+3   //function
f1(2)
val f2 = m1 _             //reuse method
f2(2)

result.msg:
m1: (x: Int)Int
res7: Int = 5
f1: Int => Int = <function1>
res8: Int = 5
f2: Int => Int = <function1>
res9: Int = 5

paragraphs.title: Filter
paragraphs.text:
%spark
val ls1 = ls.filter(e => e > 2)

val fIG2 = (e:Int) => e > 2     // rule function - Integer Greater than 2
val ls11 = ls filter(fIG2)      // function can be a parameter

// filter is a function. We treat predicate as function, if `e > 2` return  true, else false.

result.msg:
ls1: List[Int] = List(3, 4)
fIG2: Int => Boolean = <function1>
ls11: List[Int] = List(3, 4)

paragraphs.text:
%md

![filter][1]

[1]:https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rkuo/Zeppelin-Notebooks/master/2BNUH921M/images/filter2.png

paragraphs.title: Compose and Chaining

result.msg:
ls2: List[Int] = List(3, 5, 7, 9)
ls3: List[Int] = List(4, 6, 8, 10)

paragraphs.text:
%md

![compose andThen][1]

[1]: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rkuo/Zeppelin-Notebooks/master/2BNUH921M/images/composeAndThen.png

paragraphs.title: Functional Chaining
paragraphs.text:
%spark 

val fComposeG = f _ compose g    //compose function, f is a method, so need _
val fAndThenG = f _ andThen g    //chaining

val ls4 = ls.map((f _ andThen g)(_))   
val ls5 = ls.map(fAndThenG)
val ls6 = ls.map(fComposeG)
val ls7 = ls map fComposeG
val ls8 = ls map g map f
val ls9 = ls map f map g
val ls15 = ls filter fIG2 map f map g

result.msg:
fComposeG: Int => Int = <function1>
fAndThenG: Int => Int = <function1>
ls4: List[Int] = List(4, 6, 8, 10)
ls5: List[Int] = List(4, 6, 8, 10)
ls6: List[Int] = List(3, 5, 7, 9)
ls7: List[Int] = List(3, 5, 7, 9)
ls8: List[Int] = List(3, 5, 7, 9)
ls9: List[Int] = List(4, 6, 8, 10)
ls15: List[Int] = List(8, 10)

fn01: List[Int] => List[Int] = <function1>
ls16: List[Int] = List(8, 10)
ff: Int => Int = <function1>
fg: Int => Int = <function1>
ffComposeFg: Int => Int = <function1>
ls10: List[Int] = List(3, 5, 7, 9)
fncs: List[Int => Int] = List(<function1>, <function1>)
ls12: List[Int] = List(4, 6, 8, 10)
ls13: List[Int] = List(4, 6, 8, 10)
ls14: List[Int] = List(3, 5, 7, 9)

paragraphs.title: Chaining
paragraphs.text:
%md

Compare to 
```
val ls15 = ls filter fIG2 map f map g     //3, 4 andThen + 1 andThen * 2
```

There are different ways to write chaining. We can define a function to represent a chain of functions and just call it with input, see example about `ls16`. we can treat `ls` as a parameter of a functions, which is a series of transformations.

```
//define a transform function
val fn01 = (xs: List[Int]) => {xs filter fIG2 map f map g}  
val ls16 = fn01(ls)
```
There is a good [discussion on stackoverflow][1]. One comment in this discussion: "The best comments are the ones that explain why the code does something. Well-written code should make the "how" obvious from the code itself."

[1]: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6137430/documenting-scala-functional-chains?rq=1

result.msg:
Compare to

val ls15 = ls filter fIG2 map f map g     //3, 4 andThen + 1 andThen * 2

There are different ways to write chaining. We can define a function to represent a chain of functions and just call it with input, see example about ls16. we can treat ls as a parameter of a functions, which is a series of transformations.

//define a transform function
val fn01 = (xs: List[Int]) => {xs filter fIG2 map f map g}  
val ls16 = fn01(ls)

There is a good discussion on stackoverflow. One comment in this discussion: “The best comments are the ones that explain why the code does something. Well-written code should make the “how” obvious from the code itself.”

paragraphs.text:
%spark
(1 to 4).filter(_ > 2)  //Vector(3, 4)
        .map(_ + 1)     //Vector(4, 5)
        .map(_ * 2)     //Vector(8, 10)

// use defined functions     
fIG2
ff
fg
ffComposeFg

(1 to 4).filter(fIG2).map(ff).map(fg)   // same above
(1 to 4).filter(fIG2).map(fg).map(ff)
(1 to 4).filter(fIG2).map(ffComposeFg)

result.msg:
res11: scala.collection.immutable.IndexedSeq[Int] = Vector(8, 10)
res12: Int => Boolean = <function1>
res13: Int => Int = <function1>
res14: Int => Int = <function1>
res15: Int => Int = <function1>
res16: scala.collection.immutable.IndexedSeq[Int] = Vector(8, 10)
res17: scala.collection.immutable.IndexedSeq[Int] = Vector(7, 9)
res18: scala.collection.immutable.IndexedSeq[Int] = Vector(7, 9)

paragraphs.title: foldLeft and foldRight
paragraphs.text:
%md
![foldLeft and foldRight][1]

[1]:https://joelneely.files.wordpress.com/2008/04/foldlfoldr1.jpg?w=398&h=200

paragraphs.title: foldRight and foldLeft
paragraphs.text:
%spark
// http://www.nurkiewicz.com/2012/04/secret-powers-of-foldleft-in-scala.html

ls
val s4 = ls.foldLeft(0)((r, c) => (r + c))  
val s5 = ls.foldLeft(0)(_ + _)      // 0 + 1 + 2 + 3 + 4
val s6 = ls.foldLeft(1)(_ * _)      // 1 * 1 * 2 * 3 * 4
val s7 = ls.foldRight(0)(_ + _)     // 0 + 4 + 3 + 2 + 1

// val ls15 = ls filter fIG2 map f map g 
val s8 = ls15.foldLeft(1)(_ * _)   
val s9 = ls.filter(fIG2) 
           .map(f)
           .map(g)
           .foldRight(1)(_ * _)     // this filter-map-reduce, we can put all function in a list like `fncs`

result.msg:
res20: List[Int] = List(1, 2, 3, 4)
s4: Int = 10
s5: Int = 10
s6: Int = 24
s7: Int = 10
s8: Int = 80
s9: Int = 80

paragraphs.title: Reduce
paragraphs.text:
%md
If op for each node is different, then we can use `reduce`.

![reduce][1]

reduce(((val1 op1 val2) op2 val3) op3 val4)
[1]:http://thecannycoder.files.wordpress.com/2014/08/foldleft.jpg?w=272&h=300

result.msg:
If op for each node is different, then we can use reduce.

reduce(((val1 op1 val2) op2 val3) op3 val4)

res21: List[Int] = List(1, 2, 3, 4)
res22: Int = 10
res23: Int = 3
res24: Int = 2
op1: (Int, Int) => Int = <function2>
op2: (Int, Int) => Int = <function2>
res25: Int = 5
res26: Int = 18

name: Functional Programming - Function Composition and Chaining
